stream_context.summary: Kaze Emanuar worked on programming the boss fight for Course 15, a corrupted 'Pentapus' Yoshi. The stream focused on implementing the tentacle attack patterns, creating visual cues like portals and lights, setting up hitboxes, and defining the overall gameplay loop. He also discussed his design philosophies, community collaborations, and the quality of fan-made PC ports of his work.

development_findings.summary: The Course 15 boss is a corrupted 'Pentapus' Yoshi that the player must heal. The fight involves destroying weak spots ('wards') on its tentacles to make the main body vulnerable to attack.
development_findings.quote: The loop is basically, Yoshi is like floating around here at the start... tentacles come and attack and the tentacles have these wards on them... you jump on his tentacle, you destroy the ward and then Yoshi gets weak... on his nose, there's more wards. So you're going up there and you punch the ward and that's dealing damage to him.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is implementing hidden cryptographic messages in the boss's dialogue, intended as a deep easter egg for players to discover long after release.
development_findings.quote: I'm thinking for the Yoshi boss here we're actually using some cryptographic messages that we sent the player through his text boxes and I already have two encryption techniques thought of.

development_findings.summary: Kaze collaborated with a community member, Akumoid, to create a new, performance-efficient reflection shader for the game, demonstrating a willingness to incorporate community contributions.
development_findings.quote: A person called Akumoid has been DMing with me. They wanted to learn about N64 shaders and they wanted to help me make a good shader for this. And together we came up with this one here. Look at the building now. You see the reflections on it?

development_findings.summary: The game will feature nine boss fights in its main courses, a significant increase from the six in the original Super Mario 64.
development_findings.quote: We have eight boss fights, nine boss fights in the main courses... we have six boss fights in the original Mark 64, in the main courses.

development_findings.summary: The scope of the project has expanded, with the number of planned side levels potentially increasing from six to nine.
development_findings.quote: I once had planned six side levels... but nowadays there's a good chance that it's actually going to be like nine side levels.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is considering using a static recompilation tool to create a native PC port, which would improve performance and accessibility.
development_findings.quote: I might legitimately just use YSK static recompilation to properly import the game to like everything at once. So you wouldn't even need an emulator.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is implementing a 'spline hitbox' system for the boss's tentacles, a custom solution for dynamic collision detection.
Kaze plans to include levels featuring a rideable Yoshi, likely tied to a specific type of collectible star.
development_findings.quote: There's probably going to be a rideable Yoshi here somewhere else... there's probably going to be some Yoshi stats that have you ride a yoshi somewhere.

context_findings.summary: Kaze deliberately avoids expressing political opinions to maintain a broad appeal, citing the 'halo effect' as his rationale.
context_findings.quote: If no one knows what my political beliefs are, then people are more likely to assume my political beliefs overlap with theirs and they will like me for it. So I think it's better to just not talk about or not make any controversial political statements. This is what all politicians do, I'm just being honest about it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strict policy regarding community modifications of his work: he allows them as long as the creators are self-sufficient and do not ask him for support.
context_findings.quote: My general policy is if you can do it on yourself without my help, you can do with my hacks whatever you want. But as soon as you start asking me for help, I'm gonna be annoyed.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a desire for precise, technical communication, wishing people had to be able to define their terms to use them.
context_findings.quote: I had a dream one time that people were not able to say words unless they could describe exactly what they mean... I feel like if we lived in a world like that, our lives would be so much better.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reveals a past prank of hiding obscene 3D models in unused areas of his ROM hacks, visible only to other hackers, showcasing his mischievous sense of humor.
context_findings.quote: So what I did in some of my old ROM hacks is I would import the 3D model of a large cock into Castle Grounds. And not use Castle Grounds on my hack. So if you played my hack, you would see nothing wrong. But as soon as you use a ROM hacking tool to open my hack, you would just see a large cock.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is critical of low-quality ports of his work, but shows appreciation for well-executed community efforts, even if they are incomplete.

biobak.summary: Kaze's workflow with Biobak involves creating functional, placeholder models that serve as a 3D blueprint for Biobak to create the final, polished art.
biobak.quote: The textures on the boss are not final, though. They're more like a symbolic representation of what I want this to look like, so that when Biobak remakes my model, he knows what I was going for.

biobak.summary: Biobak provides concept art that serves as a basis for discussion and design direction with Kaze.
biobak.quote: There is some concept art for me and Biobak to talk to each other. And this is the concept that Biobak has sent me.

badub.summary: A viewer mentioned Badub's music is available on SoundCloud, which came as a surprise to Kaze, indicating Badub manages his own music distribution.

zeina.summary: Zeina is responsible for creating the outside area for Course 13, a task described as long-term.
zeina.quote: Course 13 is missing the outside area. Zeina wanted to work on that, she's been working on it for a long time now.

key_stories.title: The Community-Sourced Shader
key_stories.summary: A community member collaborated directly with Kaze to learn about and create a new graphical shader. The effort resulted in a visually impressive and technically efficient reflection effect that is now in the game, showcasing a positive and productive creator-community interaction.
key_stories.challenge: A community member, Akumoid, wanted to learn about N64 shaders and offered to help create one for the game.
key_stories.process: Kaze and Akumoid communicated via DMs. Akumoid learned about the N64's rendering capabilities and worked with Kaze to develop the shader effect.
key_stories.outcome: They successfully developed a new, performance-efficient reflection shader that adds significant visual polish to the game. Kaze was extremely pleased with the result and the collaboration.
key_stories.key_quote: Together we came up with this one here. Look at the building now. You see the reflections on it? I'm very happy with this... And it's a super cheap effect too.

key_stories.title: Designing the Attack Indicator Light
key_stories.summary: To solve the problem of off-screen attacks, Kaze needed a clear visual cue for the player. He prototyped and iterated on a light effect, struggling with its appearance but ultimately prioritizing gameplay clarity over perfect visual fidelity, resulting in a functional, if imperfect, solution.
key_stories.challenge: The boss's tentacles can attack from off-screen, requiring a clear visual indicator to give the player a fair chance to dodge.
key_stories.process: Kaze first implemented a subtle light effect that was too faint. He then tried a large, semi-transparent plane, which he felt looked 'super bad'. He iterated on the size, timing, and shape of the effect, ultimately settling on a functional, highly visible light cone despite its aesthetic flaws.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented a light cone that projects from the portal before the tentacle appears. While he was unhappy with the visual quality, he prioritized its gameplay function as a clear warning sign for the player.
key_stories.key_quote: But man, this looks ass. I don't like this light at all... but we need this to exist to be able to tell what's going on.

key_stories.title: Analyzing the PC Port
key_stories.summary: Kaze investigated a community-made PC port of his work on stream. He initially reacted with harsh criticism to a poor-quality version before giving a more nuanced, detailed critique of an improved version, highlighting his high technical standards and his process of evaluating community projects.
key_stories.challenge: A viewer claimed a PC port of Kaze's hack 'Peach's Fury' worked well, prompting Kaze to investigate its quality live on stream.
key_stories.process: Kaze watched a video of an old, broken port and provided harsh, specific criticism. He was then shown a more recent video. He analyzed this second video in detail, praising improvements like correct movement but pointing out specific failures like non-functional trampolines and a broken carousel.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze found the initial version to be a 'terrible port' with missing assets and broken physics. After being directed to a newer version, he acknowledged it was much better but still identified numerous rendering errors and unimplemented gameplay features, concluding it was 'very rough around theedges'.
key_stories.key_quote: Where's the water? Wait, the whole water is missing. They didn't import the water into the game... this is a terrible port, they didn't even try.
